content:
Hi. Could you please consider adding a Test where the answer is exactly k?

Currently Validator 1 has such a case but there is no Test that has such a case.

[ Motivation:

I got this clash in Shortest mode.

First I wrote a 57-bytes code that passed all the tests and ended with:

print(k-n%k)

Then, because this was shortest mode, I tried to replace that with:

print(-n%k)

(Modulo has higher precedence than binary subtraction, but lower precedence than unary negation, and python's modulo operator returns the remainder in the Euclidean division, so I thought this would save a byte. I forgot that -n%k returns 0 instead of k when n is a multiple of k.)

- The print(k-n%k) solution passes all the tests and all the validators.
- The print(-n%k) solution passes all the tests but fails validator 1!
]

Please add some test like validator 1. Otherwise it's very easy to forget that something like this will not pass.

gets
$<.map{n,k=_1.split.map &:to_i
p (k-n)%k}

The statement is very confusing and wrong in some parts.

Particularly the "Output" section:
"Output
Line 1 : An integer of the minimum number of students to join the row."
It should be "[[T]] Lines: " since you have to respond for each testcase, not just once.

Very easy puzzle that the only challenge is deciphering the overly confusing statement. :/

The statement is confusing. What's the significance of "Class 15" and "Class 21"? Why these specific numbers? They don't seem to be relevant at all. I had to solve this basically in reverse mode because the statement is not explicit enough about what is being asked.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Those are some big classes... Anyway, it works. While I needed a bit of time for studying statement and example, together with coding it is still doable in <5min.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really see no problems with this, despite the downvotes. Though I think this is good with fastest mode, preferrable over shortest mode. There may be similar clashes, but this one has large enough test cases so it isn't brute-forceable.

Change "So at least how many students should join into the end of the row to get a bag of candy?" to something like "What is the <<least number>> of students from Class 21 that can join the end of the row of [[n]] students so that one of the students from Class 21 can get a bag of candy?"

Goal section
* "blend into"? How? Is there some other way to express your intended meaning or can you think of a different narrative?

Input section
* Do you mean [[k]] instead of [[s]]?

* Please state "space-separated integers" instead of "integers".

* Please provide a brief description of what the variables T, n and k represent.

Output section
* Please be more specific.

Constraints section
* If you do mean [[k]] instead of [[s]], then the constraint of [[n]] <= [[k]] is violated by all the cases.

Thanks.

I use "join into" instead of the "blend into" to make it easier to understand.

Thanks. :smile:
Thanks, fixed. I even haven't notice this basic wrong =)
Thank you for your advise! I've already added the testcase.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "into the end of Class 15" to "the end of the row".

* Please move "at least" to between "So" and "how many".

Output section
* Please change "of the result of the question" to "the minimum number of students to join the row".

Thanks.
